skill.name: referral-program
skill.description: When the user wants to create, optimize, or analyze a referral program, affiliate program, or word-of-mouth strategy. Also use when the user mentions 'referral,' 'affiliate,' 'ambassador,' 'word of mouth,' 'viral loop,' 'refer a friend,' or 'partner program.' This skill covers program design, incentive structure, and growth optimization.
skill.summary: Design and optimize referral and affiliate programs that turn customers into growth engines.
skill.author: coreyhaines31

security_audit.summary: This skill is a documentation-only marketing guide containing no executable code, network calls, or file system operations. All static scanner detections (backtick characters, cryptographic terms, reconnaissance keywords) are false positives from markdown documentation content including ASCII diagrams, email templates, and business terminology.

content.value_statement: Referral programs drive lower customer acquisition costs and higher lifetime value, yet most companies struggle to design incentives that motivate sharing. This skill provides frameworks, templates, and proven strategies to build programs that turn customers into active growth advocates.
actual_capabilities: Design referral and affiliate program structures with appropriate incentive models
Calculate optimal reward amounts based on customer LTV and target CAC
Create email templates for referral program launch and nurture sequences
Identify trigger moments when customers are most likely to refer others
Implement fraud prevention measures to protect program integrity
Measure referral program ROI and optimize for viral coefficient
limitations: Does not implement referral tracking or attribution code
Does not integrate with specific referral software platforms
Does not provide legal terms of service for program compliance
Does not execute customer data analysis or import customer lists

use_cases.title: Launching a New Customer Referral Program
use_cases.description: A SaaS company wants to launch their first referral program. They need help designing the incentive structure, creating email templates, and setting up tracking before going to market.
use_cases.target_user: Growth marketers and product managers launching new referral initiatives

use_cases.title: Optimizing an Underperforming Affiliate Program
use_cases.description: An e-commerce brand has an affiliate program with low conversion rates. They need guidance on commission structures, affiliate recruitment templates, and strategies to improve partner performance.
use_cases.target_user: Marketing directors and affiliate program managers seeking performance improvements

use_cases.title: Preventing Referral Program Fraud
use_cases.description: A subscription business noticed suspicious referral patterns indicating abuse. They need to implement verification measures, set appropriate limits, and establish fraud prevention policies.
use_cases.target_user: Operations teams and business owners managing existing referral programs

prompt_templates.title: Getting Started with Referral Program Design
prompt_templates.prompt:
I want to design a referral program for my [B2B/B2C] [product/service type] with a customer LTV of $[amount]. Our current CAC from paid channels is $[amount]. We currently [have/do not have] an existing referral program.

Please help me:
1. Calculate the maximum referral reward we can afford
2. Recommend an incentive structure (single vs double-sided, reward type)
3. Identify the best trigger moments to ask for referrals
4. Outline the key steps to launch
prompt_templates.scenario: Initial consultation for a new referral program

prompt_templates.title: Creating Affiliate Program Commission Structure
prompt_templates.prompt:
We are setting up an affiliate program for our [product type] priced at $[amount] per [unit]. Our profit margin is [percentage]%.

Please help me design:
1. A competitive commission structure (percentage vs flat fee)
2. Tiered commission levels for top performers
3. Recommended cookie duration for our sales cycle
4. An affiliate recruitment outreach template
prompt_templates.scenario: Designing affiliate program compensation and recruitment

prompt_templates.title: Writing Referral Program Email Sequences
prompt_templates.prompt:
We are launching a referral program with the following reward: [reward details]. Our target audience is [description].

Please create:
1. A launch announcement email to existing customers
2. A nurture sequence for customers who sign up but have not yet referred
3. A re-engagement email for past referrers

For each email include subject line, body copy, and call-to-action.
prompt_templates.scenario: Creating email copy for referral program communications

prompt_templates.title: Analyzing and Optimizing Referral Program Performance
prompt_templates.prompt:
Our referral program has the following metrics:
- Referral rate: [percentage]%
- Conversion rate: [percentage]%
- Average referrals per referrer: [number]
- K-factor: [number]

[Describe the specific problem: low awareness, low share rate, low conversion, or fraud concerns]

Please analyze what might be causing this issue and recommend specific optimizations we can test.
prompt_templates.scenario: Diagnosing and fixing underperforming referral programs

output_examples.input: Design a referral program for our B2B SaaS product with $12,000 customer LTV and $500 target CAC from other channels.
output_examples.output:
**Recommended Incentive Structure:**

- **Double-sided reward:** $500 credit for referrer, $500 credit for referred (both sides benefit equally)
- **Maximum reward calculation:** ($12,000 Ã— 70% margin) - $500 = $7,900 max possible
- **Recommended range:** $200-500 to balance motivation with profitability

**Trigger Moments to Target:**
- After first major milestone achievement
- After positive support interaction
- When they publicly share results
- After renewal or upgrade

**Share Mechanism:**
1. In-product referral button (highest conversion)
2. Personalized link via email
3. Unique referral code for offline sharing

**Expected Performance Targets:**
- Referral rate benchmark: 15-25% for B2B SaaS
- K-factor goal: 0.3-0.5 (amplitied growth)

output_examples.input: Our referral program has only a 3% referral rate. Most customers sign up but never share. What should we change?
output_examples.output:
**Diagnosis: Low Share Rate Issue**

A 3% referral rate is below the 10-25% benchmark for most programs. The problem is likely one of these:

1. **Timing:** Are you asking at the right moments? Check if prompts appear after wins vs. randomly.
2. **Friction:** Is the sharing process simple? One-click sharing converts better than multi-step flows.
3. **Visibility:** Is the referral option prominent in your product? It should be visible without hunting.

**Immediate Tests:**
- Move referral prompt to appear immediately after achievement moments
- Reduce to single-click sharing with pre-filled message
- A/B test reward amounts (20% increase to test sensitivity)
- Add in-app notifications at optimal trigger points

**Quick Wins:**
- Add prominent share button in the main navigation
- Send email 7 days after signup with referral offer
- Celebrate when customers refer (social proof)

best_practices: Lead with double-sided incentives where both referrer and referred benefit, as these consistently show higher conversion rates than single-sided rewards
Identify and activate at the specific moments when customers achieve success or express satisfaction, rather than prompting at arbitrary intervals
Track referred customers separately from other channels to measure their higher LTV and lower churn, which validates continued investment in the program
anti_patterns: Waiting until customers are about to churn to ask for referrals, which feels desperate and reduces participation rates
Offering rewards so generous they attract fraudsters rather than genuine customers, requiring expensive verification systems
Making the referral process require multiple steps or account creation, which dramatically drops completion rates

faq.question: What is the difference between a referral program and an affiliate program?
faq.answer: Referral programs target existing customers who recommend to their personal networks, motivated by rewards plus helping friends. Affiliate programs target external partners like bloggers and influencers who may not be customers, motivated primarily by commissions. Many companies run both simultaneously with different structures.

faq.question: How much should I offer for a referral reward?
faq.answer: Calculate your maximum: (Customer LTV Ã— Gross Margin) - Target CAC. Typical ranges are $10-50 for B2C, $50-500 for B2B SaaS, with higher for enterprise. Start with double-sided rewards and test different amounts.

faq.question: What is a good referral rate benchmark?
faq.answer: Good referral rates are 10-25% of customers making at least one referral. Great programs achieve 25-50%. Exceptional programs with strong product-market fit and optimal timing reach 50% or higher.

faq.question: How do I prevent referral fraud and abuse?
faq.answer: Implement email verification, device fingerprinting, IP monitoring, delayed reward payouts, and require meaningful action before rewarding. Set clear terms, maximum referral limits per period, and consider paying rewards in non-transferable product credit.

faq.question: What tools should I use for referral program management?
faq.answer: Popular options include ReferralCandy and Friendbuy for e-commerce, Ambassador for enterprise programs, Viral Loops for template-based campaigns, and Rewardful for Stripe-integrated affiliate tracking. Choose based on your integration needs and scale.

faq.question: How do I measure referral program ROI?
faq.answer: Track (Revenue from referred customers - Program costs) / Program costs. Monitor cost per referred customer (CAC via referral), LTV of referred customers, payback period, and viral coefficient (K-factor). Referred customers typically show 16-25% higher LTV.
